title: The twins who tricked the Maya gods of death - Ilan Stavans

multiple-choice.question: Who were the twin brothers that initially played ball and were challenged by the lords of the underworld?

options.label: A
options.text: Junajpu and Ixb’alanke

options.label: B
options.text: The brothers of the underworld

options.label: C
options.text: The sons of the lord's daughter

options.label: D
options.text: Jun and Wuqub

multiple-choice.question: What happened to Jun's head after he was killed by the lords of the underworld?

options.label: A
options.text: It was buried in the ground

options.label: B
options.text: It was thrown into the river

options.label: C
options.text: It was given to the lord's daughter

options.label: D
options.text: It was hung from a tree as a trophy

multiple-choice.question: What was the result of the lord's daughter reaching for the fruit that grew from the tree where Jun's head was hung?

options.label: A
options.text: She was cursed with a disease

options.label: B
options.text: She was turned into a monster

options.label: C
options.text: She was banished from the underworld

options.label: D
options.text: She was impregnated with twins

multiple-choice.question: What challenges did the twins Junajpu and Ixb’alanke face in the underworld?

options.label: A
options.text: A test of their strength

options.label: B
options.text: A riddle to solve

options.label: C
options.text: A series of supernatural trials, including the House of Darkness, the House of Cold, and the House of Jaguars, and a ballgame

options.label: D
options.text: A game of ball only

multiple-choice.question: Why did the lords give the twins a torch, warning them to return it unburnt?

options.label: A
options.text: To guide them through the darkness

options.label: B
options.text: To light the way for the game

options.label: C
options.text: To make them appear foolish

options.label: D
options.text: To test their ingenuity and obedience

multiple-choice.question: How did Ixb’alanke trick the lords during the ballgame after Junajpu's head was bitten off by a bat?

options.label: A
options.text: He used a magical spell to confuse the lords

options.label: B
options.text: He hid Junajpu's head and pretended it was lost

options.label: C
options.text: He used his cunning to distract the lords

options.label: D
options.text: He carved a chilacayote squash into the likeness of Junajpu's head and swapped it with the real head

multiple-choice.question: What was the ultimate goal of the twins in their game with the lords of the underworld?

options.label: A
options.text: To win the game and gain power

options.label: B
options.text: To escape the underworld and return to the surface world

options.label: C
options.text: To perform a series of supernatural tricks

options.label: D
options.text: To defeat the lords and end their suffering of humans

multiple-choice.question: How did the twins initially protect themselves from the lords' wrath after winning the game?

options.label: A
options.text: They used their magical powers

options.label: B
options.text: They disguised themselves as disheveled children and performed tricks

options.label: C
options.text: They used their cunning and cleverness

options.label: D
options.text: They enlisted the help of seers who ensured their remains were thrown into the river, restoring them to life

multiple-choice.question: What was the final trick that the twins performed on the lords?

options.label: A
options.text: They performed a series of supernatural feats

options.label: B
options.text: They used their magical powers to defeat the lords

options.label: C
options.text: They used their cunning and cleverness to outwit the lords

options.label: D
options.text: They pretended to kill Junajpu and then resurrect him, leading the lords to demand the same trick be performed on them

multiple-choice.question: What was the result of the twins' final trick on the lords?

options.label: A
options.text: The lords were impressed and asked for more tricks

options.label: B
options.text: The lords were fooled and the twins won the game

options.label: C
options.text: The lords were angry and punished the twins

options.label: D
options.text: The lords begged for mercy, and the twins spoke their curse, stripping them of their power over the surface world and ending their suffering of humans

title: The sleep disorder you might not know you have - Alayna Vaughan

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary cause of snoring during sleep?

options.label: A
options.text: The vibration of the vocal cords

options.label: B
options.text: The relaxation of muscles around the respiratory tract, narrowing the airway

options.label: C
options.text: The sudden contractions of the diaphragm

options.label: D
options.text: The increased airflow through the nostrils

multiple-choice.question: Which sleep disorder is characterized by loud, chronic snoring and pauses in breathing during sleep due to blockages in the airway?

options.label: A
options.text: Central sleep apnea

options.label: B
options.text: Obstructive sleep apnea

options.label: C
options.text: Insomnia

options.label: D
options.text: Sleepwalking

multiple-choice.question: What is the estimated percentage of people with obstructive sleep apnea who are unaware they have the condition?
What is the primary difference between obstructive sleep apnea and central sleep apnea?

options.label: A
options.text: Obstructive sleep apnea is caused by blockages in the airway, while central sleep apnea is caused by the brain's failure to regulate breathing

options.label: B
options.text: Obstructive sleep apnea is caused by the brain's failure to regulate breathing, while central sleep apnea is caused by blockages in the airway

options.label: C
options.text: Obstructive sleep apnea occurs during REM sleep, while central sleep apnea occurs during non-REM sleep

options.label: D
options.text: Obstructive sleep apnea is more common in older adults, while central sleep apnea is more common in younger adults

multiple-choice.question: What is a common consequence of obstructive sleep apnea due to the periods of low oxygen intake?

options.label: A
options.text: Increased blood pressure and stress on the heart

options.label: B
options.text: Decreased blood pressure and relaxation of the heart

options.label: C
options.text: Increased oxygenation of the body's tissues

options.label: D
options.text: Decreased stress hormone release

multiple-choice.question: Which of the following is a risk factor for developing obstructive sleep apnea?

options.label: A
options.text: Having a smaller tongue

options.label: B
options.text: Having a larger jaw

options.label: C
options.text: Gaining weight

options.label: D
options.text: Avoiding alcohol consumption before bed

multiple-choice.question: What is a common treatment for sleep apnea that involves delivering a constant stream of pressurized air to keep the airway open?

options.label: A
options.text: Oral appliance

options.label: B
options.text: CPAP machine

options.label: C
options.text: Mouth and throat exercises

options.label: D
options.text: Surgery

multiple-choice.question: What happens to the airway during sleep that can lead to snoring?

options.label: A
options.text: It becomes wider due to the relaxation of muscles

options.label: B
options.text: It remains the same size as during wakefulness

options.label: C
options.text: It becomes narrower due to the relaxation of muscles

options.label: D
options.text: It becomes completely blocked

multiple-choice.question: What is a potential long-term consequence of untreated obstructive sleep apnea?

options.label: A
options.text: Decreased risk of cardiovascular disease

options.label: B
options.text: Improved sleep quality

options.label: C
options.text: Increased risk of hypertension and cardiovascular problems

options.label: D
options.text: Reduced risk of chronic fatigue

title: 3 secrets of resilient people - Lucy Hone

multiple-choice.question: What personal experience led the author to question the effectiveness of traditional advice on grief and to develop her own approach to resilience?

options.label: A
options.text: She experienced a sudden loss of her spouse

options.label: B
options.text: She experienced a sudden loss of her 12-year-old daughter

options.label: C
options.text: She went through a difficult divorce

options.label: D
options.text: She suffered from mental illness

multiple-choice.question: According to the author, what is the first strategy that resilient people use to cope with adversity?

options.label: A
options.text: Focusing on the positive aspects of a situation

options.label: B
options.text: Recognizing that suffering is a part of life

options.label: C
options.text: Seeking help from others

options.label: D
options.text: Avoiding problems

multiple-choice.question: What was the outcome of the experiment conducted by Martin Seligman and colleagues, as described by the author?

options.label: A
options.text: People who focused on three good things that happened to them each day showed lower levels of gratitude and happiness

options.label: B
options.text: People who focused on three good things that happened to them each day showed higher levels of gratitude and happiness

options.label: C
options.text: People who focused on three good things that happened to them each day showed no change in gratitude and happiness

options.label: D
options.text: People who focused on three good things that happened to them each day showed higher levels of depression

multiple-choice.question: What question did the author use to help her decide whether her actions were helping or harming her during her grieving process?

options.label: A
options.text: "Is what I'm doing making me happy?"

options.label: B
options.text: "Is what I'm doing helping or harming me?"

options.label: C
options.text: "Am I doing the right thing?"

options.label: D
options.text: "Is this what I want to do?"

multiple-choice.question: What is the author's main message to people who are going through a difficult time?

options.label: A
options.text: That they should avoid their problems

options.label: B
options.text: That they should focus on the negative aspects of their situation

options.label: C
options.text: That they have the ability to rise up from adversity

options.label: D
options.text: That they should give up

multiple-choice.question: How did the American army approach finding the good in difficult situations, according to the author?

options.label: A
options.text: They told soldiers to focus on the negative aspects of a situation

options.label: B
options.text: They told soldiers to hunt the good stuff

options.label: C
options.text: They told soldiers to avoid problems

options.label: D
options.text: They told soldiers to seek help from others

multiple-choice.question: What question did the author repeatedly ask herself in the days after her daughter's death?

options.label: A
options.text: "What can I do to make things better?"

options.label: B
options.text: "Is what I'm doing helping or harming me?"

options.label: C
options.text: "What can I do to make myself feel better?"

options.label: D
options.text: "Is this what I want to do?"

multiple-choice.question: According to the author, what is a key characteristic of resilience?

options.label: A
options.text: Resilience is a fixed trait that some people have and others do not

options.label: B
options.text: Resilience requires very ordinary processes that anyone can learn

options.label: C
options.text: Resilience is only for people who have experienced trauma

options.label: D
options.text: Resilience is not important for overall well-being

multiple-choice.question: How did the author find the three strategies she used to cope with her loss?

options.label: A
options.text: She found them to be ineffective in managing her grief

options.label: B
options.text: She found them to be helpful in managing her grief

options.label: C
options.text: She found them to be easy to implement, but not very helpful

options.label: D
options.text: She found them to be difficult to understand and implement

multiple-choice.question: What advice does the author give to people who are going through a difficult time and think there is no way back?

options.label: A
options.text: That they should give up and accept their circumstances

options.label: B
options.text: That they should seek help from others, but not try to change their circumstances

options.label: C
options.text: That they should lean into the strategies she has outlined and think again

options.label: D
options.text: That they should avoid their problems and focus on something else

title: The secrets of the world’s most famous symphony - Hanako Sawada

multiple-choice.question: In what year did Ludwig van Beethoven's Symphony Number Five premiere in Vienna?

options.label: A
options.text: Working as a composer for a royal court

options.label: B
options.text: Working as a freelance composer

options.label: C
options.text: Composing exclusively for religious functions

options.label: D
options.text: Teaching music at a conservatory

options.label: C

options.label: D

options.text: The inclusion of trombones, piccolo, and contrabassoon

options.label: C

options.text: From somber to triumphant

options.label: C

options.label: D

options.text: Physical disability

options.label: A
options.text: Experimentation with elements of Romanticism

options.label: B

options.label: C

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, how did Beethoven's personal struggles influence his composition of the Fifth Symphony?

options.label: A
options.text: They made his music more complex and intricate

options.label: B
options.text: They made his music more simple and straightforward

options.label: C
options.text: They allowed him to inject raw emotionality into his music

multiple-choice.question: What common interpretation is associated with the fate motif in Beethoven's Fifth Symphony?

options.label: A
options.text: It represents hope and renewal

title: The simplest math problem no one can solve

multiple-choice.question: Which mathematician famously stated that "Mathematics is not yet ripe enough for such questions" regarding the Collatz conjecture?

options.label: A
options.text: Paul Erdos

options.label: B
options.text: Luther Collatz

options.label: C
options.text: Jeffrey Lagarias

options.label: D
options.text: Terry Tao

multiple-choice.question: What distribution describes the frequency of the leading digit of numbers in a sequence and is used to detect fraud and irregularities in elections?

options.label: A
options.text: Benford's law

options.label: B
options.text: Normal distribution

options.label: C
options.text: Poisson distribution

options.label: D
options.text: Uniform distribution

multiple-choice.question: Who showed in 1976 that almost all Collatz sequences reach a point below their initial value?

options.label: A
options.text: Terry Tao

options.label: B
options.text: Jeffrey Lagarias

options.label: C
options.text: Riho Terras

options.label: D
options.text: Luther Collatz

multiple-choice.question: What does "almost all numbers" mean in the context of the Collatz conjecture?

options.label: A
options.text: A fraction of numbers that end up under a certain curve goes to one as the numbers go to infinity

options.label: B
options.text: A fraction of numbers that end up under a certain curve goes to zero as the numbers go to infinity

options.label: C
options.text: A fraction of numbers that end up under a certain curve goes to infinity as the numbers go to infinity

options.label: D
options.text: A fraction of numbers that end up under a certain curve goes to a constant value as the numbers go to infinity

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the mathematical machine created by John Conway in 1987 that generalizes the Collatz conjecture?

options.label: A
options.text: FRACTRAN

options.label: B
options.text: Collatz machine

options.label: C
options.text: Turing machine

options.label: D
options.text: Halting machine

multiple-choice.question: What is the main challenge in proving the Collatz conjecture true?

options.label: A
options.text: The conjecture is too complex to be proven

options.label: B
options.text: The conjecture is too simple to be proven

options.label: C
options.text: The space of all possibilities is too big to search exhaustively by brute force

options.label: D
options.text: The lack of a clear pattern in the Collatz sequences

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the conjecture proposed by George Polya in 1919 that was eventually proven false by C. Brian Haselgrove in 1958?

options.label: A
options.text: Polya conjecture

options.label: B
options.text: Collatz conjecture

options.label: C
options.text: Riemann hypothesis

options.label: D
options.text: P versus NP problem

multiple-choice.question: According to the video, what resource provides interactive lessons and problem-solving experiences for learners, including a course on mathematical fundamentals?

options.label: A
options.text: Brilliant

options.label: B
options.text: Coursera

options.label: C
options.text: edX

options.label: D
options.text: Khan Academy

multiple-choice.question: According to the video, what is a possible reason why the Collatz conjecture is so hard to solve?

options.label: A
options.text: The conjecture is too complex to be proven

options.label: B
options.text: The conjecture is too simple to be proven

options.label: C
options.text: The space of all possibilities is too big to search exhaustively by brute force

options.label: D
options.text: The conjecture might be undecidable

multiple-choice.question: Who showed in 2019 that almost all numbers will end up smaller than any arbitrary function f of x, so long as that function goes to infinity as x goes to infinity?

options.label: A
options.text: Terry Tao

options.label: B
options.text: Jeffrey Lagarias

options.label: C
options.text: Riho Terras

options.label: D
options.text: Luther Collatz

title: What few people know about the program that "saved" America - Meg Jacobs

multiple-choice.question: Who won the 1932 presidential election, promising a comprehensive set of legislation to support struggling citizens and put the country back to work?

options.label: A
options.text: Herbert Hoover

options.label: B
options.text: Franklin D. Roosevelt

options.label: C
options.text: Theodore Roosevelt

options.label: D
options.text: Al Smith

options.text: The Economic Recovery Act

options.label: B
options.text: The New Deal

options.label: C
options.text: The Great Depression Relief Act

options.label: D
options.text: The Job Creation Act

options.label: B
options.text: To stabilize the banking system

options.label: C
options.text: To provide direct financial assistance to states for relief programs

options.label: D
options.text: To create new government agencies

multiple-choice.question: How did the impact of the New Deal differ for Black communities in the North versus the South?

options.label: A
options.text: The North received more jobs, education, and public housing, while the South received less due to discriminatory policies

options.label: B
options.text: The South received more jobs and education, while the North received more public housing

options.label: C
options.text: The North and South received equal amounts of jobs, education, and public housing

options.label: D
options.text: The New Deal had no impact on Black communities

options.label: A
options.text: Northern liberals

options.label: B
options.text: Southern Democrats

options.label: C
options.text: Labor unions

options.label: D
options.text: The Republican Party

options.label: A
options.text: Southern Democrats

options.label: B
options.text: Northern liberals

options.label: C
options.text: Black Americans

options.label: D
options.text: Labor unions

multiple-choice.question: Why did the US economy not fully recover until the country's mobilization for World War II, despite the New Deal's efforts?

options.label: A
options.text: The New Deal's policies were ineffective

options.label: B
options.text: The Great Depression was too severe and widespread

options.label: C
options.text: The country's economy was too dependent on industrial production

options.label: D
options.text: The New Deal did not address the root causes of the economic crisis

multiple-choice.question: What was the name of the program established as part of the New Deal to employ young men in conservation projects, such as tree planting and fire prevention?

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: The Works Progress Administration

options.label: C
options.text: The Tennessee Valley Authority

options.label: D

multiple-choice.question: What were some of the key benefits of the New Deal's policies on labor?

options.label: A
options.text: Abolishing child labor

options.label: B
options.text: Granting unions the right to collective bargaining

options.label: C
options.text: Setting the first national minimum wage

options.label: D
options.text: All of the above

multiple-choice.question: What was the name of the act that established an old-age pension system, unemployment insurance, disability benefits, and welfare assistance?

options.text: The Social Security Act

options.label: B
options.text: The New Deal Act

options.label: C
options.text: The Economic Security Act

options.label: D
options.text: The Relief Act
